content.description: Follow face left of corner (tricky start), and veer right following a crack along a slab. When reaching the end, turn left and traverse further left and up (joining Circumflex).
content.location: It climbs the inside corner in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Start on the left side, and smear you way up to the left side of horizontal flake. You will pass some shallow, horizontal shelves. Continue up, and traverse right via a slab. Continue right to a left-facing corner, and climb to the top.
content.protection: The route takes plenty of gear where you need it.
content.location: This is on the left side of the wall.

content.description: Climb the face left of the corner (tricky start), and continue straight up to a right-facing corner. Follow the corner to the top.
content.location: It is left of the inside corner.

content.description: Climb the face left of the corner (tricky start), and continue straight up to a right-facing corner. Here you veer right and climb the face (left of the corner) following a drill hole.
content.location: It is left of the inside corner.

content.description: Climb up the slab and vertical crack to an undercling. Traverse right, following the undercling and feature until you join with Float Like a Butterfly (the green streak).
content.location: Start at left side of slab below a vertical crack.

content.description: Follow crack along the slab veering left to the top. There are two exit options. The right one has a high block / mantel. The left exit traverses left and up (joining Circumflex). It looks harder but is not. This is a great first lead.
content.location: This climbs the corner /crack on the far right.

content.description:
The route goes straight up. The first 20 feet or so is pretty smooth slab, although it's not horribly steep. Climbing this slab is the crux. Above that are giant blocks that you can easily clamber up to get to the anchor. 

  The good part is that there are a few features on the slab that you can lock onto. The bad part is that there's graffiti at the bottom, making it a little tough to get off the ground.
content.protection:
There's a sturdy metal staple at the top, close to the edge (5-10 feet away). There are also several metal pipes sticking up further back which can be used for anchors (20 feet away). 

  It looked like my slings would get abraded when hanging over the edge, because they tended to slip into a tight, rough crack between the rocks. I pushed a scrap of sling down in the crack to prevent this from happening.
content.location:
The route is identified as the left-most route on R Wall in Boston Rocks guide. If you come into the quarry and walk towards Knight's Wall, it's to the left, around the corner. 

  If you walk around R Wall, you'll see a large block jutting up, with a bent pipe about 20 feet to the right of it. This route goes straight up towards that tall jutting block. Currently, the route follows some light green paint drizzled down from some blocks that are below that above-mentioned jutting block. There's a "Kilroy Was Here" graffiti slightly to the left of the start. See attached photo.

content.description: Climb the face left of the corner (tricky start), and continue straight up to a right-facing corner. Here you veer slightly right and climb the face without touching the corner or left wall. It's tricky at the top.
content.location: It is left of the inside corner.

content.description: Start up the face left of the corner (tricky start), and continue up along cracks. Keep going up, slightly right along a dented slab (shallow corner) to the top.
content.location: It climbs the inside corner in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Start the same as for Bench, i.e. climb the corner and slab until a wide crack. Go right towards the arete, but now go straight up (just left of the arete).
content.location: Start at the corner / crack on the far right.

content.description: Follow corner and slab for 20 feet and a wide crack. Go right and up the arete, and finish around the corner to the right.
content.location: Start at the corner / crack on the far right.

content.description:
This is a small face that lies just to the left of North Face.  There are 2 old bolts above this face. 

  Per Steve Marr: R Face is one of the first graffiti laden craglets that you encounter when approaching the Quarries from the main parking area on Ricciuti Drive. It is a short, forty foot slab that offers a handful of moderate routes from 5.3 to 5.7. All but two of the climbs originate on the left side of the formation, while a pair of climbs and the descent route are found on the right side. Due to the fact that nearly every square inch of this wall seams to be covered with paint, none of the routes are particularly noteworthy. 

  L->R: 

  A. Ron's Arete, 3, 1p, gear.   BC. Greg's Traverse, 4, 1p, TR.   C. Float Like A Butterfly, 7, 1p, 30', TR.   D1. 100 In The Shade, 7, 1p, 30', TR.   D2. Reverberation, 5, 1p, 30', TR.   D3. Cloudburst, 6, 1p, 30', TR.   E1. Circumflex, 6, 1p, 30', TR.   E2. Seagull, 3, 1p, 30', TR.   F1. Gary's Scramble, 3, 1p, 30', gear or TR.   F2. Bench Direct, 9, 1p, 30', TR.   F3. Bench, 6, 1p, 30', TR. 

  This page is a combination of pages where the 2nd page's information was moved to this page to avoid duplication in the database.
